\"Bohemian Rhapsody\" by Queen.passage: "Bohemian Rhapsody" is a song by the British rock band Queen. It was written by Freddie Mercury for the band's 1975 album A Night at the Opera. The song has no chorus, instead consisting of three main sections: a ballad, a guitar solo, and an operatic passage. The song is known for its complex structure and multi-layered vocals, as well as its prominent use of harmonic vocals, including Queen's signature falsetto. The song has been praised for its innovative approach to rock music, and has been cited as one of the greatest songs of all time by various publications. It was a commercial success, reaching the top of the charts in several countries, including the UK, Canada, and Australia. The song's music video, which features the band members in a mock execution scene, has also become iconic and has been widely parodied and referenced in popular culture. "Bohemian Rhapsody" has been covered by numerous artists, and has been featured in numerous films and television shows. It has also been used in various sporting events, including as the official song of the 1994 FIFA World Cup. The song has been credited with helping to popularize the music video format, and has been named one of the greatest music videos of all time. Despite its success, the song has also been the subject of controversy. In 2004, the song was voted the greatest song of all time in a poll conducted by the Guinness World Records, but this decision was criticized by some music critics and industry professionals. The song's complex structure and operatic elements have also been the subject of debate, with some critics arguing that the song is overrated and overhyped.

\"Stairway to Heaven\" by Led Zeppelin.passage: "Stairway to Heaven" is a song by the English rock band Led Zeppelin, released in late 1971 as a track on their untitled fourth studio album. The song was composed by guitarist Jimmy Page and vocalist Robert Plant, and is widely considered one of the greatest rock songs of all time. The song begins with a gentle guitar arpeggio that leads into a slow, melodic guitar riff. Plant's vocals enter, singing about a woman who has left him and the memories he has of her. The lyrics then shift to a spiritual journey, with references to a "stairway to heaven" and a "saviour who is waiting to lead [the singer] home". The song's middle section features a guitar solo by Page, which is widely regarded as one of the greatest in rock history. The solo is followed by a reprise of the song's opening arpeggio, leading into a final chorus and outro. "Stairway to Heaven" was a commercial success, reaching the top 10 in the United States and the United Kingdom. It has been covered by numerous artists and has been featured in numerous films and television shows. The song has also been the subject of numerous lawsuits, including a copyright infringement lawsuit in 2016 in which the estate of Spirit guitarist Randy California claimed that "Stairway to Heaven" was based on Spirit's 1968 instrumental track "Taurus". The lawsuit was ultimately settled in favor of Led Zeppelin. Despite its commercial success, "Stairway to Heaven" has been the subject of controversy and debate among music critics and fans.

\"Hotel California\" by The Eagles.passage: The song "Hotel California" is a single by the American rock band The Eagles, released in 1976 as the title track from their album of the same name. The song is known for its distinctive guitar riff, written by Don Felder, and its haunting lyrics, written by Don Henley and Glenn Frey. The song has become one of the band's most popular and enduring hits, and is often cited as one of the greatest songs of all time. The lyrics of "Hotel California" tell the story of a weary traveler who arrives at a luxurious hotel, only to find that he is unable to leave. The hotel is described as a "place where you can check out any time you like, but you can never leave", a metaphor for the temptations of fame and fortune. The song's lyrics also touch on themes of isolation, addiction, and the fleeting nature of success. \"Imagine\" by John Lennon.passage: John Lennon's "Imagine" is a song that was released in 1971 as a single. The song was written by Lennon and produced by Phil Spector. The song is a plea for peace and unity among people, and it has become one of the most famous songs of all time. The song's lyrics are simple and direct, with Lennon singing about a world where there are no countries, no religions, and no possessions. The song's chorus is the title of the song, "Imagine," and it is sung over and over again, with Lennon's voice soaring above the music. The song's music video, which was filmed in black and white, features Lennon lying on a bed in a white room, with a woman walking around him. The video is simple and abstract, but it has become iconic and is often shown on television and in movies. "Imagine" has been covered by many artists over the years, and it has been used in many different contexts. It has been used in political campaigns, in movies, and in commercials. The song has also been used in many different languages, and it has become a symbol of peace and unity around the world. Despite its popularity, "Imagine" has also been criticized by some for being too simplistic and idealistic. Some have argued that the song's message is unrealistic and that it ignores the complexities of the world. Despite these criticisms, "Imagine" remains one of the most beloved and iconic songs of all time. Its message of peace and unity continues to resonate with people around the world, and it remains a powerful reminder of the importance of working together to create a better world.

\"Let It Be\" by The Beatles.passage: "Let It Be" is a song by the English rock band the Beatles, released in March 1970 as a single, and later included on the album of the same name, which was released in May 1970. The song was written by Paul McCartney and credited to the Lennon–McCartney partnership. The Beatles recorded "Let It Be" in January 1969, at the start of the sessions for what would become their album Abbey Road. The recording features a sparse arrangement, with a prominent acoustic guitar and a orchestral string section. The lyrics to the song reflect McCartney's belief that the Beatles' recent troubles could be overcome, and that the group would continue to make music together. \"Billie Jean\" by Michael Jackson.passage: "Billie Jean" is a song by American singer Michael Jackson. It was released by Epic Records on January 2, 1983, as the second single from his sixth studio album, Thriller (1982). It was written by Jackson and produced by Quincy Jones. "Billie Jean" is recognized as one of Jackson's signature songs and is considered one of the greatest songs of all time. The song's lyrics describe a man who is plagued by a woman claiming that he is the father of her child, despite the fact that he has never even met her. Jackson's vocal performance in the song is widely regarded as one of his best, with his vocal range and emotional delivery being particularly praised. The song's music video, directed by Steve Barron, is considered a landmark in music video history. It features Jackson dancing in a red leather jacket and white glove, and is known for its groundbreaking choreography and special effects. The video won several awards, including eight MTV Video Music Awards. "Billie Jean" was a commercial success, topping the charts in several countries, including the United States, where it spent seven weeks at number one on the Billboard Hot 100. It also became one of the best-selling singles of all time, with sales estimated at over 10 million copies worldwide. The song's success helped propel Thriller to become the best-selling album of all time, with sales estimated at over 66 million copies worldwide. "Billie Jean" has been covered by numerous artists, and its influence can be heard in many contemporary pop songs.

\"Sweet Child O' Mine\" by Guns N' Roses.term: "Sweet Child O' Mine" by Guns N' Roses
\"Sweet Child O' Mine\" by Guns N' Roses.passage: "Sweet Child O' Mine" is a song by the American rock band Guns N' Roses, written by lead guitarist Slash and vocalist Axl Rose. The song was released as a single in 1988 and is the third track on the band's second studio album, "Appetite for Destruction" (1987). It is one of the band's most famous and successful songs, and has been covered by numerous artists. The song's opening riff, played by Slash on a Gibson Les Paul, is considered one of the most iconic in rock history. The song's lyrics describe a man's love for his sweetheart, and the nostalgia he feels for his childhood. The song's music video, directed by Nigel Dick, features the band performing the song in a warehouse, intercut with footage of a young couple dancing and exploring the city. "Sweet Child O' Mine" was a commercial success, reaching the top of the Billboard Hot 100 chart in the United States and the top 10 in several other countries. It has since been certified diamond by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) for selling over 10 million copies in the US alone. The song has been included in numerous "best of" lists and is often cited as one of the greatest songs of all time. The song's popularity has endured over the years, and it remains a staple of classic rock radio playlists. In 2018, the song was inducted into the Grammy Hall of Fame.

\"Wonderwall\" by Oasis.passage: "Wonderwall" is a song by the English rock band Oasis, written by the band's guitarist and primary songwriter Noel Gallagher. The song was released as the second single from their debut album, Definitely Maybe, in 1995. It is considered one of the band's signature songs and a defining moment of the Britpop genre. The song's title is a reference to the 1968 film Blowup, in which the character played by David Hemmings repeatedly says the phrase "Wonderwall" to himself. The lyrics of the song are a mix of personal reflection and social commentary, with Gallagher singing about his feelings of isolation and disconnection from the world around him. The chorus of the song features the line "You're my wonderwall / You're my wonderwall", which has been interpreted as a declaration of love or a statement of admiration for someone who provides a sense of comfort and security. Musically, "Wonderwall" is characterized by its simple yet effective melody and the use of a tambourine to create a shimmering, dreamy effect. The song's distinctive guitar riff, played by Gallagher on an acoustic guitar, has been praised for its catchy simplicity and its ability to stick in the listener's head. The song's bridge features a harmonica solo played by former Rolling Stone Mick Gallagher, Noel's brother. "Wonderwall" was a commercial success for Oasis, reaching the top 10 in the UK and Ireland and becoming the band's first top 40 hit in the US. It has since been covered by numerous artists and has become a staple of classic rock radio.

Australia.passage: Australia is a country in the southern hemisphere. It is the world's sixth-largest country by total area. The country is known for its natural wonders and unique wildlife, such as kangaroos and koalas. It is also home to the Great Barrier Reef, the largest coral reef system in the world. Australia has a population of around 25 million people, with its capital city being Canberra. The country is a constitutional monarchy with a parliamentary democracy. It is a member of the United Nations, the Commonwealth of Nations, and the G20. Australia is considered to be one of the world's most prosperous countries and has a high standard of living. It is also a popular destination for international students and tourists.

qae_pairs.question: In what organization is Australia a member, along with the United Kingdom, Canada, and New Zealand?
qae_pairs.explanation: Australia is a member of the United Nations, the Commonwealth of Nations, and the G20.

Canada.passage: Canada is a country in North America, the world's second-largest country by area. Its territory extends from the Atlantic to the Pacific and northward into the Arctic Ocean, making it the world's third-largest country by total area. Canada's border with the United States to the south and northwest is the longest land-border in the world. Canada is sparsely populated, the majority of its land being dominated by forest and tundra. It is highly urbanized with 82% of the population concentrated in urban areas, particularly in the metropolitan areas of Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver. Canada's climate varies widely across its vast area, from temperate on the southern coast to subarctic and arctic in the north. Its capital is Ottawa, and its largest metropolitan areas are Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver. Canada is a federal parliamentary democracy and a constitutional monarchy with Queen Elizabeth II as its reigning monarch. It is a member of the Commonwealth of Nations, the United Nations, and la Francophonie.

Opera.passage: Opera is a form of classical music that originated in Italy in the late 16th century. It is a type of musical drama that is performed in an opera house, accompanied by an orchestra and a cast of singers. Opera is characterized by its use of elaborate costumes, scenery, and stage effects, as well as its use of complex musical forms and vocal techniques. Opera is typically performed in a large theater, with the audience seated in a specific area called the "house." The stage is divided into two parts: the "proscenium" and the "apron." The proscenium is the area in front of the curtain, where most of the action takes place. The apron is the area in front of the proscenium, where some of the action takes place. Opera is typically performed in a language other than the one spoken by the audience, such as Italian, French, or German. This is because opera was originally intended for the aristocracy, who were expected to be familiar with these languages. However, many operas have been translated into other languages, making them more accessible to a wider audience. Opera is divided into several different forms, including opera seria, opera buffa, and opera semiseria. Opera seria is a serious form of opera that typically features a tragic ending. Opera buffa is a comedic form of opera that is often used to provide comic relief. Opera semiseria is a form of opera that combines elements of both opera seria and opera buffa. Opera has had a significant impact on the world of music and culture. It has inspired countless composers and musicians, and has been a source of inspiration for artists in other fields, such as literature and film.

Axl Rose.passage: Axl Rose is an American singer, songwriter, and musician. He is the lead vocalist of the rock band Guns N' Roses, and has been since its inception in 1985. Rose was born William Bruce Rose Jr. on February 6, 1962, in Lafayette, Indiana. He has been known for his powerful and wide-ranging vocal abilities, as well as his energetic stage presence. Rose has been involved in several controversies throughout his career, including legal disputes with former bandmates and incidents of erratic behavior on stage. Despite this, he remains one of the most iconic and influential rock musicians of all time.

Gibson Les Paul.passage: Gibson Les Paul is a solid body electric guitar that was first sold by the Gibson Guitar Corporation in 1952. The Les Paul was designed by Gibson president Ted McCarty, with input from guitarist and inventor Les Paul. The Les Paul was originally offered with a single-cutaway mahogany body and a carved maple top, and was available with a gold top. The guitar was also equipped with two P-90 pickups, which were later replaced with humbuckers. The Les Paul was initially marketed as a high-end guitar, but it was not initially successful. However, it gained popularity in the late 1960s and early 1970s, and has since become one of the most iconic electric guitars in history. The Les Paul has been used by many famous musicians, including Jimmy Page, Slash, and Eric Clapton.

David Hemmings.passage: David Hemmings (18 November 1941 – 3 December 2003) was an English actor, film director, and film producer. He was best known for his role as the protagonist in the 1966 film Blowup, directed by Michelangelo Antonioni. Hemmings was born in Guildford, Surrey, and began his career as a child actor in the 1950s. He appeared in several films and television series in the 1960s, including The Rainbow Jacket, The Bargee, and The Troubleshooters. Hemmings also directed several films, including the 1972 film The Man on the Rock, and produced several others, including the 1976 film The Passover Plot. He died in 2003 in Barcelona, Spain, at the age of 62.

qae_pairs.explanation: David Hemmings was born in Guildford, Surrey, and began his career as a child actor in the 1950s.

Ireland.passage: Ireland (/ˈaɪərlənd/; Irish: Éire [ˈeːɾʲə]), also known as the Republic of Ireland (Irish: Poblacht na hÉireann), is a country in northwestern Europe occupying about five-sixths of the island of Ireland. The capital and largest city is Dublin, which is located on the eastern part of the island, and whose metropolitan area is home to around a third of the country's population. The state shares its only land border with Northern Ireland, a part of the United Kingdom. Ireland has a relatively small area of 70,273 square kilometres (27,136 sq mi) and is ranked 117th in the world by population, with a population of around 4.9 million people. It is a parliamentary republic with a president as head of state, a bicameral parliament, and a multi-party system. The country is a member of the European Union, the Council of Europe, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, and the United Nations. Ireland has a modern mixed economy with a focus on high-tech industries and services. The country is a member of the European Union and is an important member of the Eurozone, with its currency, the euro, being the second most widely held reserve currency in the world. The country has a high level of economic freedom, ranked 14th in the 2021 Index of Economic Freedom. Ireland is a member of the European Union and is a founding member of the Council of Europe, the OECD, and the United Nations. The country is also a member of the World Trade Organization, and a member of the European Single Market.

Noel Gallagher.passage: Noel Gallagher is an English musician, singer, and songwriter. He served as the lead guitarist, co-lead vocalist and principal songwriter of the rock band Oasis, which he founded with his brother Liam in 1991. He has also released two solo albums, "Noel Gallagher's High Flying Birds" in 2011 and "Chasing Yesterday" in 2015. Gallagher's career in music began in the late 1980s as a roadie for the Inspiral Carpets, and he went on to form Oasis with his brother Liam after being inspired by the Stone Roses. Oasis became one of the most successful bands of the 1990s and early 2000s, with hits such as "Wonderwall", "Champagne Supernova", and "Don't Look Back in Anger". Gallagher's songwriting style is often characterized by his use of melodic and poetic lyrics, and his influence on British music has been widely recognized. In addition to his music career, Gallagher is known for his outspoken personality and controversial comments, which have included criticism of other musicians and public figures.

Oasis.passage: Oasis is a British rock band formed in Manchester in 1991. Originally known as The Rain, the group was formed by guitarist and songwriter Noel Gallagher, bassist Paul "Bonehead" Arthurs, drummer Tony McCarroll, and guitarist and singer Chris Hutton. The band was renamed Oasis in 1993 after Hutton left the group. Oasis achieved worldwide success with their debut album, Definitely Maybe (1994), and followed it up with two more highly acclaimed albums, (What's the Story) Morning Glory? (1995) and Be Here Now (1997). The band's fourth album, Standing on the Shoulder of Giants (2000), was a more experimental effort that included elements of electronic music and psychedelia. Oasis's popularity and influence declined in the early 2000s, and the band went through a turbulent period marked by personnel changes, public feuds, and legal disputes. In 2009, Noel Gallagher announced that he was leaving the band, effectively ending Oasis's career. Despite their turbulent history, Oasis remains one of the most successful and influential bands of the 1990s. Their music has been described as a fusion of British rock and roll, indie rock, and elements of psychedelia, and their lyrics often deal with themes of love, loss, and social commentary. The band's legacy continues to be felt in the music of many contemporary artists.
